p: The DENV remains in nature in two cycles: urban and wild ( Weaver and Vasilakis, 2009). A. aegypti is the main vector of the urban cycle and involves only humans, and the sylvatic cycle involves nonhuman primates. Wild DENV cycles have been well documented in West Africa and Southeast Asia, but not in the Americas ( Vasilakis et al., 2011). The majority of the Colombian territory is considered endemic for DENV as 74% of the municipal capitals are below 1800 masl and have climatic conditions with temperatures ranging between 15°C and 40°C, with an average of 27°C, relative humidity of moderate to high and variable rainfall ( Chaparro-Narváez et al., 2016). In the Cordoba Department (Colombia), temperature and humidity, as well as the state of vegetation, were significantly related to the appearance of DENV ( Meza-Ballesta and Gónima, 2014). Likewise, this department is endemic to DENV, and 89.7% of the cases reported between 2001 and 2010 were concentrated on 43% of its municipalities ( Meza-Ballesta and Gónima, 2014). The average incidence of DENV between 2003 and 2010 was 36.5 cases/100,000 inhabitants, and the average mortality was 0.3 cases/100,000 inhabitants ( Alvis et al., 2015).
